1046787621048012800.text: I assume it's a performance hack so they don't exceed 512 bytes and have to return a TRUNCATE response making the client repeat the request over TCP? If true, is it valid as per the RFCs, and even if not, would it cause any interoperability issues?

1046787261902262274.text: Any DNS experts around? When querying http://ns3.cloudflare.com  for http://cloudflare.com  NS, they skip the ns7 glue for UDP, but not TCP. Is this allowed? Compare: `dig +tcp ns http://cloudflare.com  @ns3.cloudflare.com` vs `dig ns http://cloudflare.com  @ns3.cloudflare.com`

1022047112438210560.text: To the spammers spoofing my domain. You'll have better luck spamming if you pick a domain to abuse which doesn't have strictly configured DMARC.

1018932127386210309.text: When an anti-spam org sends a mailshot to an address which forwards to all of their users, and they've not locked down who can send mail to that address, and somebody Reply All's. Hello @SuretyMail

1012969614337245184.text: If you have a Pebble watch, go read https://rebble.io/  ASAP. Pebble are shutting down their servers today and you might want to import your data into Rebble. I didn't know about this deadline until I read the changes in the Android app update today.

993967332409118720.text: Some interesting email related graphs here - https://transparencyreport.google.com/safer-email/overview … - Apparently GMail is experiencing 90% of incoming and outgoing SMTP traffic over TLS nowadays. Was at ~50% only 4 years ago.

986524086913388544.text: Somebody used http://emailprivacytester.com , received the confirmation email, clicked the confirm button, sent himself a test email, then clicked the Yahoo spam button on both the confirmation email and the test email. *sigh* I'm glad I don't deal with email at scale any more.

984067169221775360.text: Was excited to see that Unbound has "DNS over TLS" support. Until I realised it doesn't support either server or client certificate authentication.

982920565114769408.text: Received a DMARC failure report from http://uwaterloo.ca  because they stripped the Received header from my email invalidating the DKIM sig, then attempted to validate SPF against their own internal RFC1918 private network address. Nice broken mail server config @UWaterloo
